header_summary: In various email threads and mailing lists, discussions revolve around blind MuSig schemes, Lightning Network development, covenants, consensus changes, coinjoin transactions, the annex feature, CivKit architecture, and a two-way peg implementation in Bitcoin Script. The need for further research, collaboration, and testing in these areas is emphasized. Specific topics include vulnerabilities in blind MuSig schemes, the complexity of the Lightning Network and the limitations of covenants, proposals for closing channels in the Lightning Network, enabling self-payment of Lightning Network invoices, collecting data on the Lightning Network for research purposes, potential damage caused by routing and on-chain fees in the Lightning Network protocol, and mitigating Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks in the Lightning Network.

recent_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
recent_posts.summary:
- @ZmnSCPxj suggests implementing the third round of MuSig1 to avoid the "Wagner" attack.
- @Tom clarifies that the discussion is about MuSig1, not MuSig2.
- @Jonas addresses the concerns and proposes an alternative scheme to prevent potential attacks.

recent_posts.title: On the experiment of the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives WG and marking this community process "up for grabs"
recent_posts.summary:
-Antoine Riard emphasizes focusing on consensus change primitives and cites taproot as a successful example.
-The authority of BOLTs is discussed, along with undocumented areas of Lightning Network operations.
-Antoine raises questions about the technical fitness of Simplicity and suggests the need for consensus.

recent_posts.title: Denial of Service using Package Relay
recent_posts.summary:
- In an email, a user expressed concern about accepting unconfirmed inputs in coinjoin transactions.
- The user warned about the risk of sender-replaced unconfirmed transactions invalidating the coinjoin.
- They discussed the advantages of package relay and upcoming RBF proposals for coinjoin security and efficiency.

recent_posts.title: Standardisation of an unstructured taproot annex
recent_posts.summary:
- Using the annex feature for Bitcoin's time-locked vaults has potential benefits, according to Antoine and Joost.
- Joost explained that the annex data is powerful for applications requiring covenants.
- Joost's demo application demonstrates how the annex ensures safety and prevents loss of funds.

recent_posts.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
recent_posts.summary:
-Front-running in peer-to-peer marketplaces was discussed in relation to the CivKit architecture.
-The concern was raised that the model resembled more of a brokerage than an exchange.
-Other security paradigms were discussed to mitigate front-running and ensure a good user experience.

recent_posts.title: Some Day Peg: A crazy two-way peg bridging BTC to other chains Raw
recent_posts.summary:
-Robin has shared an implementation of a two-way peg in Bitcoin Script on GitHub.
-The implementation allows for asset transfer between two blockchains, utilizing OP_RETURN and OP_CHECKMULTISIGVERIFY operations.
-Though not for production use, the code showcases the potential of Bitcoin Script for smart contracts and blockchain interoperability.

recent_posts.title: LN Summit 2023 Notes
recent_posts.summary:
-The Lightning Network protocol conversation covered V3 transactions, Taproot upgrade, gossip protocol versions, and more.
-It was suggested to currently limit the use of V3 transactions to unilateral closes.
-Different methods for achieving multi-sig channel parties and PTLCs were explored, along with channel jamming mitigation approaches.

recent_posts.title: option_simple_close for "unfailable" closing
recent_posts.summary:
- A new protocol for closing a channel in the Lightning Network is introduced.
- The protocol simplifies the closing process, allows fee disagreement avoidance, and includes feature options.
- Three commits are made, each modifying relevant files and providing detailed explanations for the changes.

recent_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
recent_posts.summary:
- LND supports paying invoices it generates through the `allow_self_payment` field using the API.
- An alternative method is setting up trusted channels to pay invoices without using the network.
- Currently, there is no built-in solution for self-payment, but workarounds like trusted channels exist.

recent_posts.title: An Open Source Framework to Collect Lightning Network Metrics
recent_posts.summary:
- Vincent's side project involves collecting data on the Lightning Network for research purposes.
- The project aims to track network evolution, explore solutions, and support university research.
- Detailed information and experimental tools are available through links provided by Vincent.

recent_posts.title: HTLC Endorsement for Jamming Mitigation
recent_posts.summary:
-Participants discussed potential damage in the Lightning protocol from routing fees and on-chain fees.
-A suggestion was made to vary routing fees based on node preference to prevent protocol damage.
-Reputation-based and monetary-based mitigation strategies were proposed, but challenges and limitations were acknowledged.

recent_posts.title: Computing Blinding Factors in a PTLC and Trampoline World
recent_posts.summary:
-Bastien and ZmnSCPxj discuss a proposal for a schnorr multi-hop locks mechanism, causing confusion.
-The proposal differs from the latest schnorr multi-hop locks proposal and raises questions.
-ZmnSCPxj explains their scheme, which allows flexibility and simplifies the process by eliminating lock transmission.

active_posts.title: Merkleize All The Things
active_posts.summary:
-Johan Torås Halseth implemented OP_CICV and OP_COCV in btcd, enabling interesting use cases like CoinPools.
-The reuse of taproot for output in CoinPools is common, requiring functionality similar to OP_MERKLESUB.
-Salvatore Ingala proposes using a more efficient Merkle tree to hash data once during script execution.

active_posts.title: Ark: An Alternative Privacy-preserving Second Layer Solution
active_posts.summary:
-Bob transfers bitcoins to Sally on the condition that she spends an equal amount minus a fee to Carol.
-Burak suggests that Bob can claim his previously-spent bitcoins if the service provider double spends.
-Dave raises confusion about whether Burak's scenario applies to multiple transfers and requests clarification.

active_posts.title: New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
active_posts.summary:
-Gloria Zhao proposes mempool/transaction relay policies to aid L2/contract protocols, targeting Rule 3 pinning and CPFP carve-out.
-The proposal includes rules for V3 transactions and modifications to package RBF rules for greater flexibility.
-The Bitcoin development team has suggested a new package relay policy to replace BIP125, addressing various concerns.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Transaction Relay over Nostr
active_posts.summary:
-Joost Jager proposes delegating responsibility for dealing with DoS threats in Bitcoin development.
-Dave Harding suggests relaying block templates and weak blocks in addition to individual transactions.
-Relaying weak blocks through Nostr could enhance fee estimation and facilitate transaction inclusion in blocks.

active_posts.title: Scaling and anonymizing Bitcoin at layer 1 with client-side validation
active_posts.summary:
- The LNP/BP Standards Association proposes a new scalable and anonymous layer 1 upgrade for Bitcoin called Prime.
- The upgrade moves validation work into the client-side validation system, leaving Bitcoin as money untouched.
- The proposal eliminates the need for consensus, miners upgrade, and makes layer 2 systems redundant.

active_posts.title: ZeroSync: Introducing Validity Proofs to Bitcoin
active_posts.summary:
-ZeroSync, a proof system for Bitcoin, compresses the blockchain into a compact proof of validity.
-Chain state proofs using Cairo, Utreexo, and STARKs require no consensus changes in Bitcoin.
-ZeroSync enables diverse applications and zkCoins improve privacy and throughput of token transactions, but there are concerns about potential forks and decentralization.

active_posts.title: Proposal: Bundled payments
active_posts.summary:
- ThomasV proposes extending BOLT-11 to include two bundled payments with distinct preimages and amounts.
- This proposal aims to address challenges faced by service providers in requesting prepayment and protect against mining fee attacks.
- ThomasV believes implementing bundled payments in BOLT-11 would level the playing field for lightning service providers.

active_posts.title: Liquidity griefing for 0-conf dual-funded txs
active_posts.summary:
- Liquidity griefing attacks occur when one party locks UTXOs in a shared transaction.
- Proposed solution to prevent attacks involves never locking UTXOs in dual-funded transactions.
- Nodes offering 0-conf services need to isolate UTXOs to avoid accidental double-spending.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin mail list needs an explicit moderation policy
active_posts.summary:
-Maxim Orlovsky, a bitcoin community contributor and developer, sent a post about a new protocol.
-The post was not published, leading to questions about the moderator and moderation policies.
-Orlovsky proposed solutions, including a new moderator, clear policies, and an unmoderated mail list.

active_posts.title: Lightning Network
active_posts.summary:
-The Lightning Network enables global business and scales through fast and secure lightning payments.
-Satoshi Nakamoto's lightning address, satoshi at vistomail.com, offers efficient transaction processing with unparalleled speed and security.
-Bitcoin's success and scalability are further enhanced by the Lightning Network's superior transaction processing capabilities compared to traditional banking systems.

active_posts.title: LN Summit 2024 Organization
active_posts.summary:
-Antoine, a Lightning Network (LN) developer, proposes organizing the LN Summit in Africa.
-He emphasizes the need for advanced notice due to complexities like visa travels and tropical weather.
-Antoine invites objections or feedback and encourages Lightning developers to participate for knowledge transfer.

active_posts.title: LN summit organisation (nully0x)
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Riard proposes organizing the LN Summit in Africa in June 2024.
- He believes Africa's beauty, cultural past, and financial systems make it an ideal location.
- Antoine plans to ensure fairness and transparency and invites LN developers to be part of the organization.
